head.title: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Cubans

hedline.hl1: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Cubans

abstract.p: Cecelie Counts letter, responding to June 5 article Best of Friends, Worlds Apart, in series How Race Is Lived in America, notes immigrants from many countries are startled to find they are mistaken for African-Americans, and they learn to distinguish themselves from African-Americans in order to get ahead

block.p: Black immigrants from Cuba may be learning painful lessons from their experiences in the United States, but they are also teaching us a great deal (front page, June 5).
Black immigrants from Cuba may be learning painful lessons from their experiences in the United States, but they are also teaching us a great deal (front page, June 5).

People from a wide range of countries -- Iraq, Peru, Lebanon, Brazil, Syria and Colombia, to name just a few -- are startled to find that in this country their physical attributes may cause them to be mistaken for African-American. We learn from these immigrants that people from all over the world resemble people we have been taught to think of as ''black.'' They learn quickly to distinguish themselves from African-Americans in order to get ahead.
CECELIE COUNTS Silver Spring, Md., June 9, 2000
